eral times"

> There was a dark look from RODIM=
US as he looked at NIGHTLIGHT, as if
> studying her reactions, then he nodd=
ed, "Talon?" He said, his dark
> mood passing as quickly as it came, "I sho=
uld have known. That is fine
> and well then."
> 
> He was evidently satisf=
ied in what he saw from NIGHTLIGHT's face. He
> sat down in front of his pe=
rsonal console in the room and the screen
> in front of him. He tapped in a=
 few few commands and the screen
> quickly came alive, showing the image of=
 TUSCON in dragon mode with
> several other Maximals standing around him, o=
ne of them even riding on
> his back. He appeared to be in some sort of lar=
ge prison cell, perhaps
> an excercise or work out section.
> 
> There were=
 three Sharkticon looking guards watching TUSCON and the
> others with him =
with mixtures of derision and boredom. There was no
> sound comming from th=
e screen, it was a purely visual display.
> 
> "Give me one good reason why=
 I shouldn't crush his spark." DARK
> RODIMUS said as he looked at the scre=
en, his finger tapping on the
> console in an odd beat. It meant nothing of=
 itself, but it was
> something that the old RODIMUS used to do when he was=
 trying to come
> to a decision that no one else agreed with.
